text:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should embrace the freedom offered by screens. We are finally able to keep at a distance those nosy neighbors, intrusive office workers and noisome family members. We can focus on ourselves and what we want. The age of Me is finally here again. We don't have to put on a false smile, unless we are zooming with someone. Otherwise we can look at what we want and do what we want. Even if someone is in the room with us, we don't have to acknowledge them. They also are on their screens, glued, hoping for a thumbs up, Like, or upvote. Things happening around them are inconsequential.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We can focus on ourselves and what we want. The age of Me is finally here again. We don't have to put on a false smile, unless we are zooming with someone. Otherwise we can look at what we want and do what we want. Even if someone is in the room with us, we don't have to acknowledge them. They also are on their screens, glued, hoping for a thumbs up, Like, or upvote. Things happening around them are inconsequential. 

We can now be alone with our screens, but not lonely.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should embrace the freedom offered by screens. We are finally able to keep at a distance those nosy neighbors, intrusive office workers and noisome family members. We can focus on ourselves and what we want. The age of Me is finally here again. We don't have to put on a false smile, unless we are zooming with someone. Otherwise we can look at what we want and do what we want. Even if someone is in the room with us, we don't have to acknowledge them. They also are on their screens, glued, hoping for a thumbs up, Like, or upvote. Things happening around them are inconsequential. 

We can now be alone with our screens, but not lonely.   We can connect with friends, virtually, and make virtual friends. Getting together for a chat, texting back and forth, can help us feel more valid. It can relieve loneliness, we don't have to worry about relating to a roommate. We can simply text them, if we have an issue. No need for face to face when a simple text will do. Why worry. If we tire of a lover or virtual friend,  easy, no stress. We can simply ghost. It's easy, quick and painless. We feel nothing really, no worries.

We can focus on ourselves and what we want. The age of Me is finally here again. We don't have to put on a false smile, unless we are zooming with someone. Otherwise we can look at what we want and do what we want. Even if someone is in the room with us, we don't have to acknowledge them. They also are on their screens, glued, hoping for a thumbs up, Like, or upvote. Things happening around them are inconsequential. 

We can now be alone with our screens, but not lonely.   We can connect with friends, virtually, and make virtual friends. Getting together for a chat, texting back and forth, can help us feel more valid. It can relieve loneliness, we don't have to worry about relating to a roommate. We can simply text them, if we have an issue. No need for face to face when a simple text will do. Why worry. If we tire of a lover or virtual friend,  easy, no stress. We can simply ghost. It's easy, quick and painless. We feel nothing really, no worries. 

We can also connect with people we don't know, but who share our interests.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we should embrace the freedom offered by screens. We are finally able to keep at a distance those nosy neighbors, intrusive office workers and noisome family members. We can focus on ourselves and what we want. The age of Me is finally here again. We don't have to put on a false smile, unless we are zooming with someone. Otherwise we can look at what we want and do what we want. Even if someone is in the room with us, we don't have to acknowledge them. They also are on their screens, glued, hoping for a thumbs up, Like, or upvote. Things happening around them are inconsequential. 

We can now be alone with our screens, but not lonely.   We can connect with friends, virtually, and make virtual friends. Getting together for a chat, texting back and forth, can help us feel more valid. It can relieve loneliness, we don't have to worry about relating to a roommate. We can simply text them, if we have an issue. No need for face to face when a simple text will do. Why worry. If we tire of a lover or virtual friend,  easy, no stress. We can simply ghost. It's easy, quick and painless. We feel nothing really, no worries. 

We can also connect with people we don't know, but who share our interests. We can imagine what we like in a person and pretend that the person we text or DM with is what we like. We don't have to worry about deep connections, getting along IRL, when virtual is better. We also can reduce worries of getting germs, dealing with things in a physical way, when that's not what matters now. Our "views" and buzz we create on Twitter is important. Followers count, not an actual handshake or real thumb pointing upwards, virtual traffic is the currency of today.  Embrace it. Love it.

Let's simply focus on us now. It's OUR time. So long to the centralized family, the crowded cubicle, and full bus, we can simply veg out in Jammies at home, occasionally putting on a clean shirt and prop ourselves in front of a virtual palm an boom, we are on vacation, or leading a team. Why bother with substance when appearances are all that matter. It's best to just embrace it, get on with it and excel. We can do that now.

Why wouldn't we? Just do it.

Forget competing in real life just point to what matters, our likes, followers, Reddit Karma, that's what matters. We don't have to worry about real life, we can just be ourselves, the best version of ourselves. Pretending is fun, and we can finally be what we want, not what we are. I am all for embracing it. It's time to let us control things. Revenge of the nerds is where it's at, being virtual, NOT real. Embrace it and hone it.  Real life seems too hard. We can simply withdraw and redraw our lives to fit excitement, get on with it.
